understanding.developer_understanding_on_unclear_code_: The unclear code is related to the method createMemtableAllocatorPool() which is responsible for creating a MemtablePool based on the configuration settings. The method uses the configuration values such as memtableHeapSpaceInMb, memtableOffheapSpaceInMb, memtableCleanupThreshold, and memtableAllocationType to determine the type of MemtablePool to create. The configuration settings influence the decision-making process within the method to create the appropriate MemtablePool instance.

config_description: memtable_cleanup_threshold is deprecated. The default calculation is the only reasonable choice. See the comments on  memtable_flush_writers for more information.  Ratio of occupied non-flushing memtable size to total permitted size that will trigger a flush of the largest memtable. Larger mct will mean larger flushes and hence less compaction, but also less concurrent flush activity which can make it difficult to keep your disks fed under heavy write load.  memtable_cleanup_threshold defaults to 1 / (memtable_flush_writers + 1)
developer_understanding_on_working: The memtable_cleanup_threshold configuration is used to determine the ratio of occupied non-flushing memtable size to total permitted size that will trigger a flush of the largest memtable. This value is used in the createMemtableAllocatorPool method to set the cleaningThreshold parameter when creating different types of MemtablePool based on the memtableAllocationType.
developer_understanding_on_triggering_fr: The triggering frequency of the memtable_cleanup_threshold configuration depends on the ratio of occupied non-flushing memtable size to total permitted size. When this ratio exceeds the memtable_cleanup_threshold value, a flush of the largest memtable is triggered.
developer_understanding_on_size_impact: The impact of the memtable_cleanup_threshold configuration option on the system is significant. A larger memtable_cleanup_threshold value will result in larger flushes and less compaction, but also less concurrent flush activity. This can make it difficult to keep disks fed under heavy write load. The default calculation for memtable_cleanup_threshold is 1 / (memtable_flush_writers + 1), which is considered the most reasonable choice.
